EXECUTIVE SUMMARY FOR FINCH PAPER LLC

The Finch Glens Falls Mill is a fully integrated pulp and paper mill located along the Hudson River in Glens Falls, Warren County, New York. The Mill produces more than 240,000 tons annually of premium papers for publishing, advertising, graphic arts, and business office uses, and employs approximately 607 people.

Protecting the health and safety of its employees, neighbors, and the surrounding environment is a top priority at Finch. Finch has long maintained, and has regularly reviewed and updated, a comprehensive process safety program to evaluate and reduce any risks associated with the use of chemicals in its manufacturing process. A key element of this program is the commitment to safe and proper handling of chemicals. Controls have been implemented to prevent accidental releases of hazardous substances. In the event of an accidental release, mitigation steps are taken to stop, control, contain and clean up the releases.

The Mill has four processes associated with regulated substances as defined under 40 CFR Part 68, Chemical Accident Prevention Provisions:
	Pulp Preparation  including nine, one-ton (2,000 pounds) cylinders that store chlorine gas liquified by pressure, with a maximum of three containers attached at any given time to a system of connected piping, evaporators, and eductors,  
	Wastewater Treatment  including ten, one-ton (2,000 pounds) cylinders that store chlorine gas liquified by refrigeration, with one container attached at any given time to a system of connected piping, evaporators, and injection equipment,
	Pulp Mill - Anhydrous Ammonia Handling  including piping and railcar transport of up to approximately 2,000,000 pounds of ammonia gas liquified by pressure, used in the preparation of ammonium bisulfite for the pulping process and to aid in absorption of sulfur dioxide (SO2) produced in the recovery combustion process, and
	Pulp Mill - ClO2 Bleaching  including two 80,000-gallon storage ta

nks each containing approximately 668,000 pounds of 0.95% by weight ClO2 gas liquified by refrigeration. 

The Mill has a primary goal of operating in full compliance with existing environmental regulations, which includes accurate and timely reporting and striving for steady reduction of environmental impacts. The Mill is committed to operating in a manner that is safe for its employees, the public, and the environment.

The Finch risk management program helps manage the risk involved with using hazardous substances at the Mill and complies with the requirements of the United States Environmental Protection Agencys (U.S. EPAs) 40 CFR Part 68 Accidental Release Prevention Requirements: Risk Management Program. This document is intended to satisfy the executive summary requirement of the Risk Management Program and provide the public with a description of the Finch RMP.

RMP regulations require the Mill to compile and maintain safety information related to the regulated substances subject to the Rule. Required safety information includes a Safety Data Sheet (SDS) with information on the substances physical and chemical characteristics, physical hazards, health hazards, exposure limits, and precautions for safe handling.  

The Mill maintains additional technical documentation, including an emergency preparedness plan, to help ensure that employees and local emergency responders know about the hazards associated with the Mill. The documents address:
	Physical properties of the hazardous substances handled at the Mill,
	Operating parameters for Mill equipment, and 
	Design basis and configuration information for Mill equipment.
In addition to maintaining required safety documentation, the Mill has implemented safety features specific to the hazardous substances used on-site. Each of the regulated substances is covered by unique safety features.

ANHYDROUS AMMONIA
Anhydrous ammonia is supplied in 80-ton railcars that are approved by the Department of Transportatio

n.  Ammonia is fed through a short length of flexible hose into process piping, where it is transferred to the pulp mill and to the power house. In the pulp mill, small quantities of ammonia are fed into process streams for consumption. In the power house, ammonia is mixed with a large quantity of water where it becomes diluted. If a release occurs in the ammonia piping or hose, the excess flow valve in the railcar will reduce, if not stop, the flow into the atmosphere.  In addition, the ammonia unloading area is constantly monitored in the control room by video cameras set up outside, so that operator can quickly respond to a release through remotely operated block valves.

CHLORINE
Chlorine is supplied in one-ton cylinders that are approved by both the Department of Transportation and the Chlorine Institute. Chlorine is fed through a short length of tubing into process piping.  In the pulp preparation area, the chlorine flows into large streams of process water, where it is mixed and diluted. In the wastewater treatment area, the chlorine flows into a large stream of wastewater, where it is mixed and diluted. Treatment of wastewater with chlorine is performed only occasionally. In both locations, the chlorine is stored and used inside buildings that are equipped with a scrubber capable of absorbing the contents of a full cylinder of chlorine.  In addition, the Mill has installed permanently mounted chlorine sensors at both locations to alert operators of even small chlorine leaks.

CHLORINE DIOXIDE
ClO2 is produced at the Mill in a ClO2 generator. As soon as it is generated, ClO2 is dissolved in water for storage and use in the bleaching process. Only a minor amount of pure ClO2 exists, as almost all of the ClO2 at the Mill is maintained in the solution storage tanks. The tanks are located inside a containment dike that can hold the entire contents of one of the tanks. The tanks are inspected regularly for any sign of deterioration, such as corrosion. In addition,

detectors are located in the area that will detect a release of ClO2 and activate an alarm to alert operators to a leak. Emergency response equipment is available, and personnel are trained to properly respond to any leak. Personnel may isolate any release from the piping or equipment via manual isolation valves. 

PROCESS HAZARD ANALYSIS (§ 68.67)
The Mill works with an independent consultant to perform and periodically update process hazard analyses (PHAs) of covered processes to help identify process hazards and provide recommendations that may improve the safe operation of a process. A multidisciplinary team is assembled to analyze the hazards of each Mill process. The team includes personnel with engineering and process operating experience and a leader with PHA experience. The team systematically reviews the hazards associated with operation of the equipment in the covered process areas and prepares a written report describing the results of the analysis, including a list of recommended actions. Responsibility for resolving the recommendations is assigned to area personnel, and when appropriate, changes to enhance the safety of the process are implemented.  Each PHA is revisited every five years.

RMP regulations specify the components of a Hazard Review, which includes:
	Identification of the hazards associated with a Program Level 3 process and the regulated substance,
	Safeguards used to control hazards and prevent equipment failure, 
	Conducting an OCA to investigate the potential adverse impacts of a hazardous material release,
	The five-year accident history of the hazardous material at the Mill, and
	Development of management system to oversee an accidental release prevention program.  

HAZARDS AND SAFEGUARDS
As part of the PHA process, the Mill has prepared documentation regarding the hazards specific to anhydrous ammonia, chlorine, and ClO2 used in the manufacturing process. Techniques used in the hazard analyses include the use of checklists a

nd a Hazard and Operability Analysis (HAZOP). For Mill processes involving regulated substances, major hazards identified include a toxic release, over-pressurization, corrosion, overfilling, contamination, and equipment failure.  

As safeguards, the Mill utilizes process controls including the use of relief and check valves, manual and automatic shutoffs, alarms, and rupture disks. Mitigation systems in use at the Mill include emergency scrubbers, enclosures (pulp preparation and wastewater treatment), and a secondary containment dike (surrounding ClO2 storage tanks). In addition, monitoring and detection systems are located throughout the Mill for employees to identify any hazardous releases.

OFF-SITE CONSEQUENCE ANALYSES
An OCA investigates the potential adverse impacts of hazardous material release scenarios. The impacts and analysis results depend on the characteristics of the hazardous material, specifics of the facility layout and process operations, and the physical area surrounding the facility, such as the location of the nearby residential population and environmental receptors.  

The RMP regulations require the Mill to perform an OCA to determine the maximum distance to toxic endpoint for each regulated toxic substance in exceedance of its associated Threshold Quantity. For Program Level 3 processes, the OCA must evaluate an overall worst-case release scenario and one alternative release scenario for each regulated substance for inclusion in the RMP. To simplify the analysis and establish comparable standards, the U.S. EPA has provided guidance materials for regulated sources describing how to conduct the analysis. This Report describes the analysis methodologies and assumptions incorporated into the OCA, in compliance with the U.S. EPA guidance.

The U.S. EPA guidance defines the worst-case scenario as, the release of the largest quantity of a regulated substance from a single vessel or process line failure that results in the greatest distance to a

n endpoint (U.S. EPA, 2009a). This distance is assumed to be the point where the toxic substance no longer presents a risk of serious injuries from short-term exposures, based on the substance release occurring over a short period of time under worst-case meteorological conditions. As the worst-case scenario is very unlikely, the OCA guidance also requires an alternative release scenario (for each regulated substance) to be examined.  The alternative release scenarios are based on more likely accidental release situations that would result in the toxic substance reaching an off-site endpoint.  The distances to toxic endpoints from the Mill were determined using the OCA Guidance Reference Tables and Equations. The methodologies follow the guidelines and use the associated equations for each specific type of release.

Worst-Case Scenario Analysis
The selected worst-case release scenario considers two 80,000-gallon storage tanks of an aqueous solution with a ClO2 concentration of 0.95% by weight that are both completely full prior to any accidental release. As the storage tanks are isolated and separate, the OCA worst-case evaluation only includes the possibility of a catastrophic event damaging a single vessel. The tanks are cylindrical, fully-insulated, and unpressurized vessels. The tanks are located outdoors, approximately 90 feet from ambient air along the Hudson River. The tanks are housed within a secondary containment dike that is capable of holding 110% of the total amount contained within a tank.  

For the worst-case release scenario, it is not required to consider the possible reasons for, or probability of, the release of the regulated substance. The worst-case release scenario simply occurs, and when using the U.S. EPA OCA lookup tables, the release characterization incorporates several required assumptions into the analysis:
	The total quantity of the vessel is spilled onto a flat, non-absorbing surface,
	The total quantity spilled occurs instantaneou

sly, either to a depth of one centimeter in a non-diked area or to cover the full area of a diked area,
	The release occurs at ground level, and
	The release occurs under class F atmospheric stability (stable atmosphere), a wind speed of 1.5 meters per second (m/s), 77 degrees Fahrenheit (°F) and 50 percent relative humidity.

The assumptions are intended to provide conservative, worst-case consequence distances, as opposed to accurate predictions of a potential release. 

The worst-case release of 6,338 pounds (lbs) of ClO2 can be characterized by assuming the full release occurs in ten minutes under ambient conditions, as the toxic component of a solution typically evaporates fastest during the first few minutes of a spill when concentrations are largest. Although the toxic substance will continue to evaporate from a spill pool after ten minutes, the rate of evaporation will be significantly lower and can be safely ignored in the estimation of consequence distance. For the worst-case scenario, the solution is assumed to be dense and the location is classified as urban based on the significant presence of obstructions and variable terrain near the Mill . Based on the assumptions, the worst-case release scenario would result in a greatest distance to toxic endpoint of 14 miles.  

The greatest distance to toxic endpoint was used to determine the related offsite impacts on public facilities such as businesses, special public facilities such as schools or recreational areas, and residences, as well as environmental locations, such as national or state parks, forests, or wildlife preserves. Public facilities predicted to be located within distance to the toxic endpoint include residences, schools, and major commercial/office/industrial areas. Environmental receptors (Moreau Lake State Park, Hudson Point Nature Preserve) are known to exist within the distance to the toxic endpoint. The residential population within the worst-case distance to toxic endpoint radius is a

pproximately 123,448 people, based on the 2021 vintage American Community Survey (ACS) census data available from the Missouri Census Data Center (MCDC) Circular Area Profiling System (CAPS).

Alternative Scenario Analysis  Anhydrous Ammonia
The selected alternative release scenario for anhydrous ammonia assumes a temporary leak or failure in the processing piping connecting the power house to the pulp mill at the ammonia unloading area, without active mitigation. The Mill averages 35 to 45 tons per day of ammonia to the power plant through an approximately 1,140 feet line of 1.5-inch pipe, with a flow rate of approximately 62.5 pounds per minute. The alternative release scenario assumes ammonia would be released for a 30-minute period before a Mill employee could safely stop the leak, for a total release of 1,875 pounds. In reality, such a release would be unlikely, as an accidental release would be identified by sensors located along the pipe, at the unloading station, and at the power house that would activate safety devices that would reduce, if not stop, the flow of ammonia. These safety mechanisms were disregarded for this scenario, however, in order to meet U.S. EPA requirements that the release extend off-site. 

Unlike the worst-case release scenario, there is flexibility in selection of alternative case scenarios to allow examination of climatological data or recommended values for conditions likely to be applicable to many sites. The analysis followed Guidance recommendations for the following alternative scenario assumptions:
	The release occurs at ground level, 
	The total quantity spilled occurs instantaneously, either to a depth of one centimeter in a non-diked area or to cover the full area of a diked area, and
	The release occurs under class D atmospheric stability (neutral), a wind speed of 3.0 m/s, ambient temperature of 77°F, and 50 percent relative humidity.

The greatest distance for a regulated toxic substance from the alternative scenario

is determined based on chemical-specific substance properties, local characteristics near the Mill, meteorological conditions, and the duration of the release to inform the selection of the proper Reference Table (Table 22) from the OCA guidance and identify the distance to toxic endpoint. For the ammonia alternative scenario, the solution is assumed to be dense and have the same urban land use classification as in the worst-case scenario. Based on the assumptions, the alternative release of ammonia scenario would result in a distance to toxic endpoint of 0.1 miles, reaching slightly beyond the Mill property boundary.  

The distance to toxic endpoint was used to determine the related offsite impacts on public and environmental receptors. Public receptors (residences and the Hudson River) are located within the distance to toxic endpoint. No environmental receptors are predicted to be located within the distance to the toxic endpoint. There is no residential population within the alternative release scenario for ammonia distance to toxic endpoint radius based on 2021 vintage ACS census data available from MCDC.

Alternative Scenario Analysis  Chlorine
The selected alternative release scenario for chlorine assumes the full release of a single chlorine storage tank in the Chlorine Storage Building. The chlorine storage tanks are independent, so that a complete failure would result in 2,000 pounds of chlorine being released within the building. For releases of toxic gases in an enclosed space, such as a building, the release to outside air may be lessened considerably (U.S. EPA, 2009b), and OCA guidance recommends assuming the vessel failure occurs over a ten-minute period. Based on a ten-minute release of 2,000 pounds in an enclosed space and a mitigation factor of 0.55, the alternative scenario release of chlorine is estimated at 110 pounds per minute. 

The alternative release scenario for chorine assumes the same release characteristics and climatological data as

in the alternative scenario for ammonia. Based on the assumptions and using OCA Reference Table 24, the alternative release of chlorine scenario would result in a distance to toxic endpoint of 0.2 miles, reaching slightly beyond the Mill property boundary.

The distance to toxic endpoint was used to determine the related offsite impacts on public and environmental receptors. Public receptors (residences, St. Marys  St. Alphonsus Regional Catholic School, and the Hudson River) are located within the distance to toxic endpoint. No environmental receptors are predicted to be located within the distance to toxic endpoint. The residential population within the alternate distance to toxic endpoint radius for chlorine is approximately 198 people based on 2021 vintage ACS census data available from MCDC.

Alternative Scenario Analysis  Chlorine Dioxide
The selected alternative release scenario for ClO2 assumes that a purge valve to the atmosphere from one of the two 80,000-gallon ClO2 storage tanks fails or is opened in error, releasing ClO2 into the containment dike for a period of 20 minutes before a Mill employee could safely stop the leak. The leak is assumed to have the same release rate (634 pounds per minute) as the worst-case release scenario and results in a total release of 12,680 pounds.

The alternative release scenario for ClO2 assumes the same release characteristics and climatological data as in the alternative scenario for ammonia and chlorine. Based on the assumptions and using OCA Reference Table 21, the alternative release scenario of ClO2 would result in a distance to toxic endpoint of 6.8 miles.

The distance to toxic endpoint was used to determine the related offsite impacts on public and environmental receptors. Public and environmental receptors (Moreau Lake State Park, Hudson Point Nature Preserve) are located within the distance to toxic endpoint. The residential population within the alternate distance to toxic endpoint radius for chlorine is

approximately 76,296 people based on 2021 vintage ACS census data available from MCDC.

FIVE-YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY
RMP regulations require the Mill to provide a five-year accident history for each regulated toxic substance.  Based on 40 CFR 68.42(a), the five-year accident history covers only releases that have caused on-site deaths, injuries, or significant property damage or known off-site deaths, injuries, property damage, environmental damage, or sheltering in place.

The Mill reported an accidental release of chlorine on May 10, 2019 at approximately 10:25 a.m. An amount of less than one pound of chlorine was released due to equipment failure of a joint during maintenance activities, with the release estimated to occur for five minutes. The release resulted in one employee seeking on-site medical treatment, but did not result in property or environmental damage. As a result of the accident, revised maintenance procedures were developed.

The Mill reported an accidental release of ammonia on June 10, 2019 at approximately 1:45 p.m. An insignificant amount of ammonia residual was released when unhooking a railcar, with the release estimated to occur for two minutes. The release was due to an improper maintenance procedure. The release resulted in two employee injuries, but did not result in property or environmental damage. As a result of the accident, equipment was upgraded and revised training and operating procedures were developed.

The Mill did not have any accidents involving ClO2 in the previous five years.

MANAGEMENT SYSTEM
The Environmental Manager is responsible for maintaining this document and associated records, as well as retaining a file copy of any previous versions of the RMP. The Mill Manager is responsible for maintaining the Mill Prevention Program and Emergency Response Program incorporated by reference.

The Mill will review and update the OCA at least once every five years. To document that the OCA has been reviewed and updated, the submit

ted copy will be retained onsite. If a change occurs in the process that may result in an increase or decrease in the distance to the endpoint by a factor of two or more, the Mill will complete a revised analysis within six months of the change and submit a revised RMP.

OPERATING PROCEDURES (§ 68.69)
Mill process engineers, operators, and managers collaborate to develop and maintain operating procedures to define how tasks related to process operations should be safely performed. The operating procedures are used to train employees and serve as reference guides for appropriate actions to take during both normal operations and process upsets.  Operating procedures include:
	Steps for safely conducting process operations activities,
	Applicable safety information, such as safe operating limits and consequences of process deviations, and
	Safety and health considerations, such as chemical hazards, personal protective equipment requirements, and actions to take if exposure to a hazardous substance occurs. 

TRAINING (§ 68.71)
The Mill trains employees to safely and effectively perform their assigned tasks. The Mill safety program includes both initial and refresher training that covers a general overview of Mill processes, the properties and hazards of the substances in each process, and a detailed review of process operations procedures and safe work practices. Oral reviews are used to verify that an employee sufficiently understands the training material prior to the employee beginning or resuming work in the process.

MECHANICAL INTEGRITY (§ 68.73)
The Mill maintains process equipment to help prevent equipment failures that could endanger employees, the public, or the environment. The mechanical integrity and preventative maintenance program includes:
	An inspection and testing program to help identify equipment deterioration and damage prior to equipment failure, and
	A quality assurance program to help ensure that new and replacement equipment meets the stric

t design standards required for service in each process

MANAGEMENT OF CHANGE (§ 68.75)
The Mill evaluates and specifically approves all proposed changes to chemicals, equipment, technology, and procedures to help ensure that the change does not negatively impact safe operations. All changes, other than a replacement in kind (e.g., replacing a valve with an identical valve), must be approved through the full management of change program. The approval process helps ensure that inadvertent consequences of process changes are prevented, safety consequences of changes are addressed, affected process safety information and procedures are updated, and affected employees are notified of the changes. 

PRE-STARTUP REVIEW (§ 68.77)
The Mill recognizes that new or newly modified processes are historically more likely to be involved in accidental releases. Therefore, the Mill performs safety review of new or modified processes before placing them into service to help ensure their safe operation. Pre-startup reviews confirm:
	Construction and equipment are in accordance with design specifications, 
	Adequate safety, operating, maintenance, and emergency procedures are in place, 
	Employee training has been completed, and
	For a covered process, a PHA has been performed if the process is new or management of change requirements have been completed if an existing process has been modified.

COMPLIANCE AUDITS (§ 68.79)
One of the cornerstones of an effective prevention program is conducting regular, thorough assessments. The Mill audits covered processes every three years to be certain that the Mill prevention program is effectively addressing the safety issues of our operations. The Mill assembles an audit team that includes personnel knowledgeable in the PSM and RMP rules and in process designs, and the team evaluates whether the prevention program satisfies the requirements of the two rules and whether it sufficiently ensures safe process operations. Audit results are doc

umented, recommendations are resolved, and appropriate enhancements to the prevention program are implemented.

INCIDENT INVESTIGATION (§ 68.81)
Under a Program 3 Prevention Program, the Mill is required to investigate any instance that resulted in, or could have resulted in, a catastrophic release of a regulated substance. The United States Environmental Protection Agency defines a catastrophic release as a release that presents an imminent and substantial endangerment to public health and the environment. 

The Mill investigates all incidents that could reasonably have resulted in a serious injury to personnel, the public, or the environment to ensure that similar future incidents can be prevented. The Mill trains its employees to identify and report any incident requiring investigation. In the event of an incident, an investigation team is assembled and the investigation is initiated within 48 hours of the incident. The results of the investigation are documented, recommendations are resolved, and appropriate process improvements are implemented. 

The RMP Rule requires incident investigations and associated reports to include:
	Date, time, and location of the incident,
	Description of the incident,
	The amount of release and duration of the incident,
	Consequences of the incident,
	Emergency response actions,
	Factors contributing to the incident, and 
	Root cause analysis.

The Mill will maintain summaries of any incident investigation and the resulting recommendations for corrective actions for five years and include the incident information in the five-year accident history of the RMP.

EMPLOYEE PARTICIPATION (§ 68.83)
The Mill has developed a written employee participation program for covered processes to ensure that the safety concerns of Mill employees are adequately addressed. The Mill encourages active participation of all personnel in the prevention program activities associated with all Mill processes. Employees are consulted on, and informed

about, all aspects of the Mills accidental release prevention program.

HOT WORK PERMIT (§ 68.85)
The Mill has established a hot work permit program to control activities to control spark-producing or flame-producing activities that may result in a fire or explosion in covered processes. The Mill has reviewed OSHA fire prevention and protection requirements and has developed a hot work permit form to comply with these requirements. Mill personnel who are to perform hot work are required to complete the form. The appropriate supervisor then reviews the completed form prior to commencing hot work. Training in the use of the hot work permit form is included in the Mills safe work practices orientation.

CONTRACTORS (§ 68.87)
The Mill has established a program to help ensure that contractor activities are performed in a safe manner. The program reviews the safety record of all candidate contractors to help ensure that the Mill only hires contractors who can safely perform the requested tasks. The Mill explains to contract supervisors the hazards of each process on which they and their employees will work, Mill safe work practices, and Mill emergency response procedures. The contractor is required to ensure that training has been performed for each of their employees who will work at the Mill prior to the worker commencing work. Additionally, the Mill periodically reviews contractors training documents and work performance history to help ensure that safe practices are followed.

EMERGENCY PLANNING AND RESPONSE (§ 68.95)
The Mill has established a written emergency response program to help safely respond to accidental releases of hazardous substances. Communication with team members and contractors occurs on formal and informal levels to ensure complete understanding of the required actions in the event of an emergency. The written plan includes procedures for:
	Informing the Warren County Local Emergency Planning Committee (LEPC) about accidental releases that could

reasonably result in offsite consequences,
	Providing proper first aid and emergency medical treatment for accidental human exposure to hazardous substances, 
	Controlling and containing accidental releases of hazardous substances, including the use of emergency response equipment, and
	Reviewing and updating the emergency response plan.

The Mill maintains a team that is trained to respond to emergency situations, and the Plant Manager is in charge of coordinating emergency actions. All Mill personnel are trained in evacuation procedures. The Environmental Control Manager is responsible for notifying the Warren County LEPC of any emergency situation, and the LEPC is responsible for notifying the public, if necessary. In addition, the Mill currently has one professional employee participating in the Warren County LEPC, ensuring regular dialogue between the Mill and local emergency officials.

The written emergency response plan complies with other federal contingency plan regulations [OSHA Regulation 29 CFR 1910.38 and 29 CFR 1910.120(a); Clean Water Act Regulation 40 CFR 112] and a copy of the plan is maintained at the Mill.

CONTINUOUS IMPROVEMENT
It is the expectation of the Mill to implement continuous improvement in its safety and environmental programs. The Mill strives to improve the safety of all processes using recommendations developed through the prevention program, soliciting safety suggestions from employees, and implements changes when deemed warranted.

RISK MANAGEMENT PLAN SUBMITTAL
The regulations at 40 CFR 68.150 require that the owner or operator of a stationary source subject to the Risk Management Program rule submit a single RMP to the U.S. EPA. This plan is due for the Mill prior to exceeding the storage concentration threshold for a Regulated Toxic Substance.  The information required by the RMP is dictated by the regulations. The RMP is due for renewal every five years.  

The contents of the RMP plan will follow the requirements of 40 C

FR Part 68, Subpart G, and include:
	Executive Summary
	Registration
	Offsite Consequence Analysis
	5-year Accident History
	Prevention Program Data
	Emergency Response Data
	Certification

The format of the electronic submission has been established by the U.S. EPA using the RMP*eSubmit system accessible at the Central Data Exchange (CDX). The Mill last submitted a filing via RMP*eSubmit on June 5, 2018.
